subs.text: March 7

@ThordaksMommy @RonWenig @mehdirhasan #ITER construction is far along. 
 -> operation 2025-2035+

See, e.g.: @iterorg @fusionforenergy 

-> First commercial prototype designs 10 years later?

-> Wide adoption maybe by 2075? 
(_maybe_ 2065 if we’re lucky/committed?)

See also #SPARC project by 
@mit_nse / @CFS_Energy

subs.text:
@constanceshortc @Heykki80 @jmkorhonen @Bundeskanzler There were reports from over a week ago, during the first nights of the evacuation: separation of those with Ukrainian passports and those without (due to EU migration rules).

Fixed 1 day later when the entire EU agreed to allow visa for anyone who had been living in Ukraine…
subs.rawText:
@constanceshortc @Heykki80 @jmkorhonen @Bundeskanzler There were reports from over a week ago, during the first nights of the evacuation: separation of those with Ukrainian passports and those without (due to EU migration rules).

Fixed 1 day later when the entire EU agreed to allow visa for anyone who had been living in Ukraine…

subs.text:
@constanceshortc @Heykki80 @jmkorhonen @Bundeskanzler (also for clarity, it would have been border authorities on the Moldovan / Romanian /Hungarian / Slovakian / Polish side of the border)

On the major crossings, both humanitarian NGO volunteers and foreign embassy personnel from many nations (to aid their citizens) are on-site.
subs.rawText:
@constanceshortc @Heykki80 @jmkorhonen @Bundeskanzler (also for clarity, it would have been border authorities on the Moldovan / Romanian /Hungarian / Slovakian / Polish side of the border)

On the major crossings, both humanitarian NGO volunteers and foreign embassy personnel from many nations (to aid their citizens) are on-site.

subs.text: @constanceshortc @Heykki80 @jmkorhonen @Bundeskanzler (The only people who are limited from departure are fighting-age male Ukrainian citizens, for understandable reasons)

subs.text:
@Heykki80 @jmkorhonen @constanceshortc @Bundeskanzler I’ve read that Germany currently has several _months_ of natural gas reserves; 1/5 of that may be controlled by a Russian-owned company, 

… but that still gives them plenty to survive the winter / springtime, at _current_ usage levels, assuming _zero_ foreign gas imports.
subs.rawText:
@Heykki80 @jmkorhonen @constanceshortc @Bundeskanzler I’ve read that Germany currently has several _months_ of natural gas reserves; 1/5 of that may be controlled by a Russian-owned company, 

… but that still gives them plenty to survive the winter / springtime, at _current_ usage levels, assuming _zero_ foreign gas imports.

subs.text:
@Heykki80 @jmkorhonen @constanceshortc @Bundeskanzler … and in any case, if supply was somehow constrained, it’s not domestic heating that would be blocked first but rather energy supply for factories / industry.

So, there are likely significant corporate interests in keeping energy cheap. Follow the money.
subs.rawText:
@Heykki80 @jmkorhonen @constanceshortc @Bundeskanzler … and in any case, if supply was somehow constrained, it’s not domestic heating that would be blocked first but rather energy supply for factories / industry.

subs.text:
@MSzafranski413 @DanLamothe Keep in mind someone saying they “cannot corroborate” something doesn’t mean they can’t have detailed confirmed intelligence on a topic.

Not having permission to corroborate something can also result in that response, and the IC will ultimately share only what it wants to share.
subs.rawText:
@MSzafranski413 @DanLamothe Keep in mind someone saying they “cannot corroborate” something doesn’t mean they can’t have detailed confirmed intelligence on a topic.

Not having permission to corroborate something can also result in that response, and the IC will ultimately share only what it wants to share.

subs.text: @mairtinofaolain @cormacleane @evangershkovich From what little I’ve read, yes, these sorts of markings are indeed temporary and meant to be applied immediately prior to a battle - ostensibly to maximize (visual) IFF ability and minimize chances for enemy spoofing.
subs.rawText: @mairtinofaolain @cormacleane @evangershkovich From what little I’ve read, yes, these sorts of markings are indeed temporary and meant to be applied immediately prior to a battle - ostensibly to maximize (visual) IFF ability and minimize chances for enemy spoofing.

subs.text:
@mairtinofaolain @cormacleane @evangershkovich (They could be as simple as a chalk/lime-type whitewash instead of actual paint?

i.e. something cheap / easy to apply, and relatively easy to remove.)
subs.rawText:
@mairtinofaolain @cormacleane @evangershkovich (They could be as simple as a chalk/lime-type whitewash instead of actual paint?

i.e. something cheap / easy to apply, and relatively easy to remove.)

subs.text:
@cormacleane @mairtinofaolain @evangershkovich Unverified:

V - Marines
Z - Eastern Military District
Z in a square - Southern Military District (Crimea)
O - units from Belarus
X - forces of Ramzan Kadyrov, Putin installed warlord of Chechnya 
A - Russian Special Forces(SSO) (e.g. Spetznaz)
subs.rawText:
@cormacleane @mairtinofaolain @evangershkovich Unverified:

V - Marines
Z - Eastern Military District
Z in a square - Southern Military District (Crimea)
O - units from Belarus
X - forces of Ramzan Kadyrov, Putin installed warlord of Chechnya 
A - Russian Special Forces(SSO) (e.g. Spetznaz)

subs.text: @Burn_the_fleet @Zingarella9 @BarakRavid Oh, of course. 😉 It also seems that maintaining a low altitude could be quite useful when tracking / discriminating high-altitude objects. They seemed to be interested in keeping their port side towards the other flight as much as possible, and now #RTB. Coincidence; my bad. [link]
subs.rawText:
@Burn_the_fleet @Zingarella9 @BarakRavid Oh, of course. 😉 

It also seems that maintaining a low altitude could be quite useful when tracking / discriminating high-altitude objects.

They seemed to be interested in keeping their port side towards the other flight as much as possible, and now #RTB.

Coincidence; my bad. https://t.co/lsklbw8SL2

subs.text:
@aydincalik90 @shadihamid It’s the nuclear weapons.

Letting Russia get away with this sort of thing only strengthens the logical/strategic case for nations like Iran to continue to rapidly develop new weapons and for the DPRK, India, France, Pakistan, Israel, etc. to maintain their current inventories.
subs.rawText:
@aydincalik90 @shadihamid It’s the nuclear weapons.

Letting Russia get away with this sort of thing only strengthens the logical/strategic case for nations like Iran to continue to rapidly develop new weapons and for the DPRK, India, France, Pakistan, Israel, etc. to maintain their current inventories.

subs.text: Agenda item 5 resolution (A/ES-11/L.1) passes @UN #GeneralAssembly during the Emergency Special Session #11 (convened to address the #Russian attacks inside #Ukraine). Vote results: 141-5 (with 35 abstentions) Full text (English): [link] #UNCharter #ESS11
subs.rawText:
Agenda item 5 resolution (A/ES-11/L.1) passes @UN #GeneralAssembly during the Emergency Special Session #11 (convened to address the #Russian attacks inside #Ukraine).

Vote results: 141-5 (with 35 abstentions)

Full text (English): 
https://t.co/v40n4cl5a0
#UNCharter #ESS11

subs.text: March 1

@markproxy Reminds me of something recently read in a Corey book:

“There is nothing in that message. Nothing. He is walking around his words like they’ve got poisoned spikes on them. And what’s he got? Threats. No one makes threats.”
subs.rawText:
@markproxy Reminds me of something recently read in a Corey book:

“There is nothing in that message. Nothing. He is walking around his words like they’ve got poisoned spikes on them. And what’s he got? Threats. No one makes threats.”
